fields.description:
We would like to use a proxy to send API requests to CLC and Walrus Endpoints on behalf of the actual client.

The reasoning behind that is to use a URL like this for example:

{code}
http://clc.eucalyptus-cloud.com
http://walrus.eucalyptus-cloud.com
http://euare.eucalpytus-cloud.com
{code}

In order to achieve this we setup an apache based httpd server that uses mod_proxy to proxy requests.

Following configuration was used:

{code}
<VirtualHost *>
    ServerName clc.eucalyptus-cloud.com
    ProxyRequests Off
    <Proxy *>
        Order deny,allow
        Allow from all
    </Proxy>
    ProxyPass / http://10.104.1.168:8773/services/Eucalyptus
    ProxyPassReverse / http://10.104.1.168:8773/services/Eucalyptus
    <Location />
        Order allow,deny
        Allow from all
    </Location>
</VirtualHost>
<VirtualHost *>
    ServerName euare.eucalyptus-cloud.com
    ProxyRequests Off
    <Proxy *>
        Order deny,allow
        Allow from all
    </Proxy>
    ProxyPass / http://10.104.1.168:8773/services/Eucalyptus
    ProxyPassReverse / http://10.104.1.168:8773/services/Euare
    <Location />
        Order allow,deny
        Allow from all
    </Location>
</VirtualHost>
<VirtualHost *>
    ServerName walrus.eucalyptus-cloud.com
    ProxyRequests Off
    <Proxy *>
        Order deny,allow
        Allow from all
    </Proxy>
    ProxyPass / http://10.104.1.168:8773/services/Walrus
    ProxyPassReverse / http://10.104.1.168:8773/services/Walrus
    <Location />
        Order allow,deny
        Allow from all
    </Location>
</VirtualHost>
{code}

As can be seen above, we have setup 2 Virtual hosts for both the CLC as well as Walrus.

*Walrus*

The client code uses following Endpoint for Walrus

{code}
http://walrus.eucalyptus-cloud.com
{code}

The signature calculation inside the client happens with the above URL only (no port, no service path, no SSL, only access key and secret key)

The client then tries to get a list of all buckets on the cloud. 

The request hits the httpd proxy as DNS resolver , resolves walrus.eucalyptus-cloud.com to the httpd server IP.

The proxy would then reach out to the actual Walrus server on correct port i.e. 8773 and service path i.e. /services/Walrus/ on behalf of the client.

When the request reaches Walrus, it successfully authenticates the request because of EUCA-5275 and prepares the response, sends it back to the proxy, which then sends it to the client.

The wire trace is shown below

{code}
####
T 10.104.1.151:55061 -> 10.104.1.150:8773 [AP]
GET /services/Walrus/ HTTP/1.1 
Host: 10.104.1.150:8773 
Authorization: AWS XMBBFJDYDY5CRK7MFY3IH:xnZy5hWprz1XOE9T5j9WNmLJZFg= 
Date: Mon, 15 Apr 2013 07:22:22 GMT 
User-Agent: aws-sdk-java/1.4.0 Mac_OS_X/10.8.3 Java_HotSpot(TM)_64-Bit_Server_VM/20.14-b01-447 
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8 
X-Forwarded-For: 10.8.0.6 
X-Forwarded-Host: walrus.eucalyptus-cloud.com 
X-Forwarded-Server: walrus.eucalyptus-cloud.com 
Connection: Keep-Alive 
 

##
T 10.104.1.150:8773 -> 10.104.1.151:55061 [AP]
HTTP/1.1 200 OK 
Content-Length: 1001 
Content-Type: application/xml 
 
<ListAllMyBucketsResult xmlns="http://s3.amazonaws.com/doc/2006-03-01/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><Owner><ID>979477180823</ID><DisplayName>eucalyptus</DisplayName></Owner><Buckets><Bucket><Name>centos6</Name><CreationDate>2013-03-22T11:06:52.132Z</CreationDate></Bucket><Bucket><Name>ubuntu-img</Name><CreationDate>2013-03-31T06:44:15.944Z</CreationDate></Bucket><Bucket><Name>ubuntu-kernel</Name><CreationDate>2013-03-31T06:41:55.064Z</CreationDate></Bucket><Bucket><Name>centos6-kernel</Name><CreationDate>2013-03-22T11:17:23.759Z</CreationDate></Bucket><Bucket><Name>centos6-ramdisk</Name><CreationDate>2013-03-22T11:18:55.507Z</CreationDate></Bucket><Bucket><Name>ubuntu-ramdisk</Name><CreationDate>2013-03-31T06:42:34.139Z</CreationDate></Bucket><Bucket><Name>centos6-img</Name><CreationDate>2013-03-22T11:21:10.550Z</CreationDate></Bucket><Bucket><Name>testbucket</Name><CreationDate>2013-04-12T17:30:36.346Z</CreationDate></Bucket></Buckets></ListAllMyBucketsResult>
##
{code}


*CLC*

For CLC we would need to use the AWS Signature version 4 mechanism to calculate the signature based upon the appropriate URL i.e.

{code}
http://clc.eucalyptus-cloud.com
{code}

Eucalyptus 3.3.0 implements AWS Signature version 4 , see EUCA-2537 and EUCA-4648 for the following commit https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/commit/101d85ff049bd81475f51c70984a69d12e667e43

Currently AWS JAVA SDK 1.4.0 does not default to using Signature v4 for EC2 and hence we could not test this implementation, i.e. is to use Signature v4 for CLC coupled with apache mod_proxy.

*Euare (IAM)*

This is an addition to this request.  Same as the CLC:

{code}
http://euare.eucalyptus-cloud.com
{code}

We would like to confirm if the AWS SDK IAM functionality will work on the CLC(s) coupled with apache/nginx proxy set up.

*Goal*

The request is to have QA run through a series of test (API calls) against this kind of setup, so we feels comfortable setting up an apache proxy or nginx based reverse proxy to send API requests to Eucalyptus cloud.

This would then eliminate the patching of the various tools and the SDKs to support custom port and service paths ( EUCA-3443 )
fields.summary: Using a Proxy to handle EC2 and IAM API Requests with CLC and S3 API Requests with Walrus

comments.body:
Additional Notes:

AWS does not seem to officially support Signature version 4 for EC2 yet , please see the following link:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/signature-version-4.html

So we really need something similar to EUCA-5275 for CLC service path as well.

Also on another note signature version 4 is supported by AWS IAM so it should work with IAM services in Eucalyptus as well, also the proxy should be able to handle these requests without the service path and port.
Confirming this one to move to the bug scrub.  The action in the scrub is to review the request to determine viability and scope.
[~hspencer], do we understand how these work in an HA environment, especially after failover?
This should work without a proxy, what specifically is the proposed change for this issue?

So I assume that if this works without a proxy then we can close this issue and if it does not work without a proxy we should capture/fix those problems, rather than adding support for an additional (proxy) layer.

Is there any reason to keep this issue open?
IMO if we can document how to do this without a proxy, and it works, then we can close this issue.  If it doesn't work without a proxy, I agree, we should capture/fix those problems.

[~hspencer],

As of 4.0, the need for providing a path following the URL (e.g. http://[hostname]:[port]/[path]) to contact the services when using DNS is no longer required. The services can now be reached by pre-pending the component name like walrus and objectstorage in front of the hostname (e.g. http://[component].[hostname]:[port]). 

This resolve having to provide the path string when using DNS. The only part that is left of is that we still have to provide the port number. To resolve this last item, there are 3 options available:

1) The obvious option of not doing anything and document the requirement that a port needs to be specified to communicate between web services

or;

2)  If, for a few only, providing a port as part of the URL is an issue, then can be provided with (or pointed at) instructions on how to setup a proxy server that will translate our URLs (e.g. walrus.qa1.eucalyptus.com) to the URL plus the port (i.e. walrus.qa1.eucalyptus.com:8773). Another option would be to use ip tables to rewrite HTTP request on port 80 to 8773. These are only providing workaround solutions to a simple problem for a few.

or;

3) If providing a port with the URL is a major issue for the mass, then we need to fix the services themselves and allow for the web services to configure an additional port and let the customer decide to intentionally use a specific port (like 80 and/or 8080).

Port 8773 is required for the components to bootstrap. To bootstrap ALL of the components, we need a predicable port that we know will work on all systems which it appears that port 80 is sometimes block on systems. This is why services, today, do listen on a port other than the standard ports.

[~hspencer],

I also tested the 1.5.0.0 ec2-ami tools when working on EUCA-7043 and found out that the --url option is in the process of being deprecated.

This issue was previously scheduled to be worked on in more than one sprint:
* '3.3 Sprint 4' (on board 'Test 3.3 Board')
* '3.3 Sprint 4' (on board 'Copy of 3.3 Release Board')

Starting from JIRA Agile 6.3, an issue can only belong to a single future sprint. Read more about this change: http://docs.atlassian.com/agile/docs-0640/Sprint+Marker+Migration

This issue is now scheduled for future sprint '3.3 Sprint 4' (on board 'Copy of 3.3 Release Board').

If this is incorrect, please update the issue accordingly.

This comment was automatically generated by JIRA. If it is no longer relevant, please feel free to delete it.
The echo Steve and Chuck is there any reason why this issue is still open?
I think this issue should be closed.
Using Eucalyptus DNS and changing ports to 80 and 443 via cloud properties, this is no longer an issue.
